review.title: Compliant Conditions for Polynomial Time Approximation of Operator Counts
review.abstract: In this brief abstract, we develop a computationally simpler version of the operator count heuristic for a particular class of domains. The contribution of this abstract is thus threefold, we (1) propose an efficient closed form approximation to the operator count heuristic; (2) leverage compressed sensing techniques to obtain an integer approximation in polynomial time; and (3) discuss the relationship of the proposed formulation to existing heuristics and investigate properties of domains where such approaches are useful.

sections.heading: Relation to Existing Heuristics.
sections.text: The proposed heuristics have strong associations with both the heuristics of state change equations and the number of operators [8, 3, 10]. Especially compliant conditions capture the net change criteria very succinctly and are therefore extremely useful where such properties are relevant. Another interesting link to existing work is in relation to graph-based heuristics [2], except here we relax preconditions instead of deleting effects.

sections.heading: Compliance.
sections.text: Our approach works better in areas with many target-conforming conditions, e.g. in manufacturing areas [6] or in puzzles such as Sudoku [1]. Therefore, goal completion strategies and semantic conservation measures have a direct influence on the quality of heuristics. Interim representations such as Transition Normal Form (TNF) [7] should be investigated in this context.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we develop a computationally simpler version of the operator count heuristic for a particular class of domains. The contribution of this abstract is threefold, we (1) propose an efficient closed form approximation to the operator count heuristic using the Lagrangian dual; (2) leverage compressed sensing techniques to obtain an integer approximation for operator counts in polynomial time; and (3) discuss the relationship of the proposed formulation to existing heuristics and investigate properties of domains where such approaches appear to be useful.
